[[File:COLBERT patch.jpg|thumb|200px|[[NASA]]'s [[Combined Operational Load-Bearing External Resistance Treadmill]] (C.O.L.B.E.R.T.) is named after comedian [[Stephen Colbert]].]] A '''backronym''', or '''bacronym''', is a constructed phrase that purports to be the source of a word that is an [[acronym]]. Backronyms may be invented with either serious or humorous intent, or they may be a type of [[false etymology]] or [[folk etymology]].
An [[acronym]] is a word derived from the initial letters of the words of a phrase:<ref name="dict-ref-acronym"> {{cite web| url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/acronym | title=Acronym | work = Dictionary.com |accessdate=2006-11-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061028021324/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Acronym| archivedate= 28 October 2006 | deadurl= no}} </ref> For example, the word ''[[radar]]'' comes from "radio detection and ranging".<ref name="nasa"> {{cite web |url= http://www.nasaexplores.com/show_k4_teacher_st.php?id=030703122033 |author= NASA |authorlink= National Aeronautics and Space Administration |work= Nasa Explores |title= RADAR means: '''Ra'''dio '''D'''etection '''a'''nd '''R'''anging }}{{dead link|date=August 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} </ref><!-- this was chosen because more people are familiar with radar than RAM: ~~~ -->
By contrast, a backronym is constructed by creating a new phrase to fit an already-existing word, name, or acronym. For example, the [[United States Department of Justice]] assigns to its [[Amber Alert]] program the meaning "America's Missing: Broadcast Emergency Response,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amberalert.gov/ |title=AMBER Alert - America's Missing: Broadcast Emergency Response |publisher=Amberalert.gov |date=2007-11-01 |accessdate=2010-07-08| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100727174209/http://www.amberalert.gov/| archivedate= 27 July 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref> but the term originally referred to [[Amber Hagerman]], a 9-year-old abducted and murdered in [[Texas]] in 1996.
Backronyms are often used for comedic effect, as when [[NASA]] named its [[International Space Station|ISS]] treadmill the Combined Operational Load-Bearing External Resistance Treadmill (C.O.L.B.E.R.T.) after [[Stephen Colbert]]. The backronym was a lighthearted compromise in recognition of the comedian's ability to sway NASA's online vote for the naming of an ISS module later named ''[[Tranquility (ISS module)|Tranquility]]''.<ref name="colbert">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/colberttreadmill.html |title=COLBERT Ready for Serious Exercise |publisher=[[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] |date=2010-10-23 |accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref>
<!-- Please don't change 'combination' to 'portmanteau'. It is likely to start a silly edit war. See Talk Archive 3 and Talk Archive 1 for some past arguments about the wording. --> The word is a combination of ''backward'' and ''acronym'', and has been defined as a "reverse acronym".<ref name="wordspy">{{cite web |url=http://www.wordspy.com/words/bacronym.asp |accessdate=2009-05-19 |first=Paul |last=McFedries |authorlink=Paul McFedries |title=bacronym |work=Word Spy: The World Lover's Guide to New Words |publisher=[[WordSpy.com]] }}</ref> Its earliest known citation in print is as "bacronym" in the November 1983 edition of the ''[[Washington Post]]'' monthly [[neologism]] contest.<!--2 refs if needed: https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/local/longterm/colmnst/levey/levey.htm#neologism and http://www.fun-with-words.com/neologisms_competition.html--> The newspaper quoted winning reader Meredith G. Williams of [[Potomac, Maryland]], defining it as the "same as an acronym, except that the words were chosen to fit the letters".<ref name="wordspy"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Levey|first1=Bob|title=When You Can't Decide, You Just Pick Them All|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1983/11/08/when-you-cant-decide-you-just-pick-them-all/fbd4bf9c-b383-4e55-9bd7-508cb9f69f1b/|date=November 8, 1983|website=washingtonpost.com|publisher=The Washington Post|accessdate=22 January 2016}}</ref>
==Examples== <!-- PLEASE: Do not add new backronyms without citations and mentioning SIGNIFICANCE on [[Talk:Backronym]] This is a list of examples. It is ''not'' meant to be exhaustive. This section illustrates a concept; it's not an anthology. Please suggest items on the talkpage first, and make sure there's a [[wp:rs]] reliable source. New items should be in wide circulation. --> {{Globalize|section|date=April 2015}}
Backronyms can be constructed for educational purposes, for example to form [[mnemonic]]s. An example of such a mnemonic is the [[Apgar score]], used to assess the health of newborn babies. The rating system was devised by and named after [[Virginia Apgar]], but ten years after the initial publication, the backronym ''APGAR'' was coined in the US as a mnemonic learning aid: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity and Respiration.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://profiles.nlm.nih.gov/CP/Views/Exhibit/narrative/obstetric.html|publisher=U.S. National Library of Medicine, NIH|title=The Virginia Apgar Papers - Obstetric Anesthesia and a Scorecard for Newborns, 1949-1958| accessdate=2008-11-18 }}</ref>
[[Alcoholics Anonymous]] and other [[Twelve-step programs|12-step programs]] use backronyms as teaching tools, similar to slogans such as "one day at a time", or "Let go, let God", but often with an ironic edge. For example, a ''slip'' may be expanded as "Sobriety Losing Its Priority",<ref> {{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gf4y3fdElKgC&pg=PA79&dq=%22Sobriety+losing+its+priority%22|title=Keep Coming Back: Humor and Wisdom for Living and Loving Recovery by Meiji Stewart Google Books Result|accessdate=2008-07-08 | isbn=978-1-56838-378-1 | year=1999 | publisher=Hazelden Publishing}}</ref> and ''denial'' as "Don't Even Notice I Am Lying".<ref name="12-steps-recovery.com">{{cite web|author=Lord Wolf Designs |url=http://12-steps-recovery.com/library/acronyms.html |title=Recovery Related Acronyms and Meanings for A.A. & N.A. use |publisher=12-steps-recovery.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-08}}</ref>
Backronyms are also created as jokes or as slogans, often expressing consumer loyalties or frustration. For example, the name of the restaurant chain ''[[Arby's]]'' is a play on the letters "RB", referring to the company's founders, the Raffel brothers. An advertising campaign in the 1980s created a backronym with the slogan "America’s Roast Beef, Yes Sir!"<ref>{{cite web|last=Gross |first=Daniel |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2234863/ |title=Too Much Beef: Why Arby's is so low on the restaurant food chain. |publisher=Slate.com |date=2009-11-07 |accessdate=2010-07-08}}</ref>
Some backronyms name the subject to make obvious its purpose or characteristics; the [[GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast bomb]] (abbreviated [[MOAB]]) and others in the series were heavily promoted by the [[United States]] as the "Mother of All Bombs", a backronym during the [[Iraq War]]. US news coverage in the days leading up to the United States [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] claimed "Mother of All Bombs" to be the US response to [[Saddam Hussein]]'s phrase "mother of all battles" from the first Gulf War.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/03/12/air-force-tests-mother-all-bombs/ |title=Air Force Tests 'Mother of All Bombs' |publisher=Fox News |date=2003-03-12 |accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref>
In [[commercial aviation]], [[ETOPS]] is officially an acronym for Extended-range Twin-engine Operational Performance Standards,<ref>{{cite web|title=CAP 789: Requirements and Guidance Material for Operators |url=http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/33/CAP%20789.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Civil Aviation Authority |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=2014-03-24 |quote=Extended Range Twin Operations (ETOPS) Pre-Departure Service Check |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141127112145/http://www.caa.co.uk/docs/33/CAP%20789.pdf |archivedate=2014-11-27 |df= }}</ref> defining safety standards for long-distance over-water flights by planes with only two engines, but in aviation vernacular, the colloquial backronym is "Engines Turn Or Passengers Swim."<ref>{{cite book|last=Bowen |first=John T. |title=The Economic Geography of Air Transportation: Space, Time, and the Freedom of the Sky|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BlyLAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA285|date=5 April 2010 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-135-15657-2 |page=285 |quote=In the dark humor common in the airline industry, ETOPS is sometimes translated as "engines turn or passengers swim," but in actual practice, the safety of twinjets on over-water routes has been outstanding}}</ref>
Many companies or products have spawned multiple humorous backronyms, with positive connotations asserted by supporters or negative ones by detractors. For example, the car company [[Ford]] was said to stand for "First On Race Day", by [[aficionados]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.competitionplus.com/2006_07/dick_brannan.html |title=Drag Racing's Internet Magazine |publisher=Competition Plus.com |date= |accessdate=2010-07-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091023131543/http://www.competitionplus.com/2006_07/dick_brannan.html |archivedate=2009-10-23 |df= }}</ref> but disparaged as "Fix Or Repair Daily", by critics.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jalopnik.com |url=http://jalopnik.com/5879789/the-definitive-guide-to-derogatory-auto-acronyms |title=The definitive guide to derogatory auto acronyms |date=2012-01-27 |accessdate=2014-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=BusinessBalls.com |url=http://www.businessballs.com/acronyms.htm |title=acronyms and abbreviations |publisher=Business Balls.com |date=2014-08-20 |accessdate=2014-08-20}}</ref> Similar backronyms have been directed against many other automakers, such as "Fix It Again Tony" for [[Fiat]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/motors/2009/0506/1224245982906.html| title=Fix it again, Sergio – and then fix the rest of 'em | date=May 6, 2009| publisher=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=September 25, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newser.com/story/57710/fiat-has-long-shed-fix-it-again-tony-reputation.html |title=Fiat Has Long Shed 'Fix It Again Tony' Reputation |first1=John |last1=Johnson |publisher=Newser |date=April 30, 2009 |accessdate=October 5, 2012}}</ref>
Backronyms have also been coined by military personnel during wartime. The backronym for [[Spam (food)|Spam]], "Something Posing As Meat", was said to have originated from [[jaundiced]] soldiers who were sick of eating canned meat.<ref>{{cite book|title=New Words for Old: Recycling Our Language for the Modern World|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VPO4CgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|first=Caroline|last=Taggart|publisher=[[Michael O'Mara Books]]|date=2015|isbn=9781782434733}}</ref> The British contribution to the [[2003 invasion of Iraq]] was code-named "[[Operation Telic]]", meaning "directed or tending to a definite end", from the Greek word {{lang-grc|τέλος|telos|label=none}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/telic|title=telic - Definition of telic in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English}}</ref> The meaning was initially unknown but as initial planning took place over the Christmas 2002 period, the term became jokingly known amongst service personnel as a backronym for "Tell Everyone Leave Is Cancelled".<ref>{{cite book|title=Bullet Magnet: Britain's Most Highly Decorated Frontline Soldier|author-link=Mick Flynn|first=Mick|last=Flynn|publisher=[[Hachette (publisher)|Hachette UK]]|date=2010|isbn=9780297860013}}</ref>
Backronyms are sometimes created to name laws or programs. The official title of the [[Patriot Act|USA PATRIOT Act]], a 2001 [[Act of Congress|Act of the U.S. Congress]], is "Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism (USA PATRIOT) Act of 2001".<ref>Public Law #56 of the 107th Congress {{USPL|107|56}}</ref> Commentators have noted a trend among US lawmakers to devise names that form a desired acronym.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cohen|first=Micah|title=The Most Powerful Special Interest in Washington: The Acronym|work=FiveThirtyEight|date=May 19, 2012|url=https://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/19/the-most-powerful-special-interest-in-washington-the-acronym/ |access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
===As false etymologies=== Sometimes a backronym is so commonly heard that it is widely but incorrectly believed to have been used in the formation of the original word, and amounts to a [[false etymology]] or an [[urban legend]]. Examples include [[wikt:posh|''posh'']]{{anchor|POSH}}, an adjective describing stylish items or members of the upper class. A popular story derives the word as an acronym from "Port Out, Starboard Home", referring to nineteenth century first-class cabins on [[ocean liners]], which were shaded from the sun on outbound voyages east (e.g. from Britain to [[British India|India]]) and homeward heading voyages west.<ref name="posh"> {{cite book|title=Port Out, Starboard Home: And Other Language Myths|publisher=Penguin Books|last=Quinion|first=Michael|isbn=0-14-101223-4|year=2005}}; published in the US as {{cite book|title=Ballyhoo, Buckaroo, and Spuds|last=Quinion|first=Michael|year=2006|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=0-06-085153-8}}</ref> The word's actual etymology is unknown, but more likely related to [[Romani language|Romani]] ''påš xåra'' ("half-penny") or to [[Urdu]] (borrowed from Persian) ''safed-pōśh'' (one who wears "white robes"), a derogatory term for wealthy people.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |year=2009 |title =posh, ''adj.'' and ''n.'' |encyclopedia=Oxford English Dictionary |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford}}</ref>
Lexicographer [[Jesse Sheidlower]] writes in his book [[The F-Word (book)|''The F-Word'']] that acronyms were rare in the English language prior to the twentieth century, and most etymologies of common words or phrases that suggest origin from an acronym are false.<ref name=F-word>{{Cite book |last1=Sheidlower |first1=Jesse |authorlink1=Jesse Sheidlower |title=The F-Word |location=New York |publisher=Oxford University Press US |year=2009 |isbn=0-19-539311-2}}</ref>
Other examples include the brand name ''[[Adidas]]'', named after company founder [[Adolf Dassler|Adolf "Adi" Dassler]] but falsely believed to be an acronym for "All Day I Dream About Sports";<ref name="adidas book">All Day I Dream About Sport: The Story of the Adidas Brand, {{ISBN|1-904879-12-8}}</ref> ''[[Wiki]]'', said to stand for "What I Know Is",<ref name="economist-wiki">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/surveys/displaystory.cfm?story_id=6794228|title=The wiki principle|work=Economist.com|accessdate=2006-11-15|date=2006-04-20| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061007095842/http://www.economist.com/surveys/displaystory.cfm?story_id=6794228| archivedate= 7 October 2006 | deadurl= no}}</ref> but in fact derived from the [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] phrase ''wiki-wiki'' meaning "fast";<ref name="dict-ref-wiki">{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/wiki|title=wiki - Definitions from Dictionary.com|accessdate=2006-11-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061206015347/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/wiki| archivedate= 6 December 2006 | deadurl= no}}</ref> or [[Yahoo!]], sometimes claimed to mean "Yet Another Hierarchical Officious Oracle", but in fact chosen because Yahoo's founders liked the word's meaning of "rude, unsophisticated, uncouth".<ref name="Yahoo-Info">{{cite web |title=The History of Yahoo! - How It All Started... |url=http://docs.yahoo.com/info/misc/history.html |date=2001 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011129061649/http://docs.yahoo.com/info/misc/history.html |archive-date=29 November 2001 |work=Yahoo.com |accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref>
The distress signal [[SOS]] is often believed to be an abbreviation for "Save Our Ship" or "Save Our Souls". In fact, it was chosen because it has a simple and unmistakable Morse code representation{{snd}} three dots, three dashes, three dots, all sent without any pauses between characters.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rohrer |first=Finlo |title=Save our SOS |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/7444184.stm |publisher=BBC News Magazine |date=13 June 2008 |accessdate=2012-07-10}}</ref>

revision.comment: Clarified that it is not in all cases that enantiomers have different biological effects. Added missing references.
revision.text: {{other uses}} [[Image:Chirality with hands.svg|200px|thumb|Two enantiomers of a generic [[amino acid]] that is '''chiral''']] '''Chirality''' {{IPAc-en|k|aɪ|ˈ|r|æ|l|ɪ|t|iː}} is a property of [[asymmetry]] important in several branches of science. The word ''chirality'' is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] {{lang|el|χειρ}} (''kheir''), "hand," a familiar chiral object. An object or a system is ''chiral'' if it is distinguishable from its [[mirror image]]; that is, it cannot be [[wikt:superposed|superposed]] onto it. Conversely, a mirror image of an ''achiral'' object, such as a sphere, cannot be distinguished from the object. A chiral object and its mirror image are called ''enantiomorphs'' (Greek, "opposite forms") or, when referring to molecules, ''[[enantiomers]]''. A non-chiral object is called ''achiral'' (sometimes also ''amphichiral'') and can be superposed on its mirror image. If the object is non-chiral and is imagined as being colored blue and its mirror image is imagined as colored yellow, then by a series of rotations and translations the two can be superposed, producing green, with none of the original colors remaining. The term was first used by [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Lord Kelvin]] in 1893 in the second [[Robert Boyle Lecture]] at the [[Oxford University Junior Scientific Club]] which was published in 1894: {{quote|I call any geometrical figure, or group of points, 'chiral', and say that it has chirality if its image in a plane mirror, ideally realized, cannot be brought to coincide with itself.{{cite journal |title=The Molecular Tactics of a Crystal |author=Sir William Thomson Lord Kelvin | year=1894 | publisher=[[Clarendon Press]] | url=https://archive.org/details/moleculartactic00kelvgoog}}}} Human [[hand]]s are perhaps the most universally recognized example of chirality. The left hand is a non-superimposable mirror image of the right hand; no matter how the two hands are oriented, it is impossible for all the major features of both hands to coincide across all axes.Georges Henry Wagnière, ''On Chirality and the Universal Asymmetry: Reflections on Image and Mirror Image'' (2007). This difference in symmetry becomes obvious if someone attempts to shake the right hand of a person using their left hand, or if a left-handed glove is placed on a right hand. In mathematics, ''chirality'' is the property of a figure that is not identical to its mirror image. ==Mathematics== [[File:Orbifold 2X.2.svg|thumb|200px|An achiral 3D object without central symmetry or a plane of symmetry]] [[Image:Knot table.svg|thumb|200px|right|A table of all [[prime knot]]s with seven [[Crossing number (knot theory)|crossings]] or fewer (not including mirror images).]] {{main|Chirality (mathematics)}} In [[mathematics]], a figure is chiral (and said to have chirality) if it cannot be mapped to its mirror image by [[Rotation (mathematics)|rotation]]s and [[Translation (geometry)|translation]]s alone. For example, a right shoe is different from a left shoe, and clockwise is different from anticlockwise. See {{cite journal | author = Petitjean, M. | title = Chirality in metric spaces. In memoriam Michel Deza | journal = Optimization Letters | year = 2017 | doi = 10.1007/s11590-017-1189-7}} for a full mathematical definition. A chiral object and its mirror image are said to be enantiomorphs. The word ''enantiomorph'' stems from the Greek {{lang|grc|ἐναντίος}} (enantios) 'opposite' + {{lang|grc|μορφή}} (morphe) 'form'. A non-chiral figure is called achiral or amphichiral. The [[helix]] (and by extension a spun string, a screw, a propeller, etc.) and [[Möbius strip]] are chiral two-dimensional objects in three-dimensional ambient space. The J, L, S and Z-shaped ''[[tetromino]]es'' of the popular video game [[Tetris]] also exhibit chirality, but only in a two-dimensional space. Many other familiar objects exhibit the same chiral symmetry of the human body, such as gloves, glasses (where two lenses differ in prescription), and shoes. A similar notion of chirality is considered in [[knot theory]], as explained below. Some chiral three-dimensional objects, such as the helix, can be assigned a right or left handedness, according to the [[right-hand rule]]. ===Geometry=== In [[geometry]] a figure is achiral if and only if its [[symmetry group]] contains at least one ''orientation-reversing'' isometry. In two dimensions, every figure that possesses an [[axis of symmetry]] is achiral, and it can be shown that every ''bounded'' achiral figure must have an axis of symmetry. In three dimensions, every figure that possesses a [[plane of symmetry]] or a center of symmetry is achiral. There are, however, achiral figures lacking both plane and center of symmetry. In terms of [[point groups]], all chiral figures lack an improper axis of rotation (Sn). This means that they cannot contain a center of inversion (i) or a mirror plane (σ). Only figures with a point group designation of C1, Cn, Dn, T, O, or I can be chiral. ===Knot theory=== A [[knot (mathematics)|knot]] is called [[amphichiral knot|achiral]] if it can be continuously deformed into its mirror image, otherwise it is called chiral. For example, the [[unknot]] and the [[figure-eight knot (mathematics)|figure-eight knot]] are achiral, whereas the [[trefoil knot]] is chiral. {{clear|both}} ==Physics== [[Image:Circular.Polarization.Circularly.Polarized.Light Right.Handed.Animation.305x190.255Colors.gif|thumb|200px|Animation of left-handed (anticlockwise), [[circularly polarized]], [[light]] as viewed in the direction of the source, in agreement with [[physics]] and [[astronomy]] conventions.]] {{main|Chirality (physics)}} In physics, chirality may be found in the [[Spin (physics)|spin]] of a particle, where the handedness of the object is determined by the direction in which the particle spins.{{cite web|url=http://discovermagazine.com/1995/nov/lookingfortherig591|title=Looking for the Right Hand - DiscoverMagazine.com|author=|date=|website=discovermagazine.com|accessdate=23 March 2018}} Not to be confused with [[Helicity (particle physics)|helicity]], which is the projection of the spin along the linear momentum of a subatomic particle, chirality is a purely quantum mechanical phenomenon like spin. Although both can have left-handed or right-handed properties, only in the massless case do they have a simple relation.{{cite web|url=http://www.quantumdiaries.org/2011/06/19/helicity-chirality-mass-and-the-higgs/|title=Quantum Diaries|author=|date=|website=www.quantumdiaries.org|accessdate=23 March 2018}} In particular for a massless particle the helicity is the same as the chirality while for an antiparticle they have opposite sign. The ''handedness'' in both chirality and helicity relate to the rotation of a particle while it proceeds in linear motion with reference to the human hands. The thumb of the hand points towards the direction of linear motion whilst the fingers curl into the palm, representing the direction of rotation of the particle (i.e. clockwise and counterclockwise). Depending on the linear and rotational motion, the particle can either be defined by left-handedness (ex. translating leftwards and rotating counterclockwise) or right-handedness (ex. translating in the right direction and rotating clockwise). A symmetry transformation between the two is called [[parity (physics)|parity]]. Invariance under parity by a [[Dirac fermion]] is called ''chiral symmetry''. ===Electromagnetism=== {{main|Chirality (electromagnetism)}} [[Electromagnetic radiation|Electromagnetic]] wave [[Wave propagation|propagation]] as [[handedness]] is wave [[Polarization (waves)|polarization]] and described in terms of [[Circular dichroism|helicity]] (occurs as a helix). Polarization of an [[electromagnetic wave]] is the property that describes the [[Orientation (geometry)|orientation]], i.e., the [[periodic function|time-varying]], direction ([[Euclidean vector|vector]]), and [[amplitude]] of the [[electric field]] vector. For a depiction, see the adjacent image. ==Chemistry== [[File:Zwitterion-Alanine.png|thumb|right|200px|(''S'')-Alanine (left) and (''R'')-alanine (right) in zwitterionic form at neutral pH]] {{main|Chirality (chemistry)}} A ''chiral molecule'' is a type of [[molecule]] that has a non-superposable [[mirror image]]. The feature that is most often the cause of chirality in molecules is the presence of an [[asymmetric carbon|asymmetric carbon atom]].''Organic Chemistry'' (4th Edition) Paula Y. Bruice.''Organic Chemistry'' (3rd Edition) Marye Anne Fox, James K. Whitesell. The term "chiral" in general is used to describe the object that is non-superposable on its mirror image.{{GoldBookRef|title=chirality|file=C01058}} In chemistry, chirality usually refers to molecules. Two mirror images of a chiral molecule are called [[enantiomer]]s or optical [[isomer]]s. Pairs of enantiomers are often designated as "[[right-handed|right-]]", "left-handed" or if it has no bias achiral. As polarized light passes through a chiral molecule, the plane of polarization, when viewed along the axis toward the source, will be rotated in a clockwise (to the right) or anticlockwise (to the left). A right handed rotation is dextrorotary (d); that to the left is levorotary (l). The d- and l-isomers are the same compound but are called [[enantiomers]]. An equimolar mixture of the two optical isomers will produce no net rotation of polarized light as it passes through.{{cite book|last1=Chang|first1=Raymond|title=Chemistry|publisher=[[Random House]]|isbn=0-394-32983-X|page=660|edition=second}} Left handed molecules have l- prefixed to their names; d- is prefixed to right handed molecules. Molecular chirality is of interest because of its application to [[stereochemistry]] in [[inorganic chemistry]], [[organic chemistry]], [[physical chemistry]], [[biochemistry]], and [[supramolecular chemistry]]. More recent developments in chiral chemistry include the development of chiral inorganic nanoparticles that may have the similar tetrahedral geometry as chiral centers associated with sp3 carbon atoms traditionally associated with chiral compounds, but at larger scale.{{Cite journal|last=Moloney|first=Mícheál P.|last2=Gun'ko|first2=Yurii K.|last3=Kelly|first3=John M.|date=2007-09-26|title=Chiral highly luminescent CdS quantum dots|url=https://doi.org/10.1039/b704636g|journal=Chemical Communications|language=en|volume=0|issue=38|doi=10.1039/b704636g|issn=1364-548X}}{{Cite journal|last=Schaaff|first=T. Gregory|last2=Knight|first2=Grady|last3=Shafigullin|first3=Marat N.|last4=Borkman|first4=Raymond F.|last5=Whetten|first5=Robert L.|date=1998-12-01|title=Isolation and Selected Properties of a 10.4 kDa Gold:Glutathione Cluster Compound|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/jp9830528|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|volume=102|issue=52|pages=10643–10646|doi=10.1021/jp9830528|issn=1520-6106}} Helical and other symmetries of chiral nanomaterials were also obtained.{{Cite journal|last=Ma|first=Wei|last2=Xu|first2=Liguang|last3=de Moura|first3=André F.|last4=Wu|first4=Xiaoling|last5=Kuang|first5=Hua|last6=Xu|first6=Chuanlai|last7=Kotov|first7=Nicholas A.|date=2017-06-28|title=Chiral Inorganic Nanostructures|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00755|journal=Chemical Reviews|volume=117|issue=12|pages=8041–8093|doi=10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00755|issn=0009-2665}} ==Biology== {{See also|Homochirality}} All of the known life-forms show specific chiral properties in chemical structures as well as macroscopic anatomy, development and behavior.{{Cite journal|last=Xiao|first=Wende|last2=Ernst|first2=Karl-Heinz|last3=Palotas|first3=Krisztian|last4=Zhang|first4=Yuyang|last5=Bruyer|first5=Emilie|last6=Peng|first6=Lingqing|last7=Greber|first7=Thomas|last8=Hofer|first8=Werner A.|last9=Scott|first9=Lawrence T.|date=2016-02-08|title=Microscopic origin of chiral shape induction in achiral crystals|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nchem.2449|journal=Nature Chemistry|language=En|volume=8|issue=4|pages=326–330|doi=10.1038/nchem.2449|issn=1755-4330}} In any specific organism or evolutionarily related set thereof, individual compounds, organs, or behavior are found in the same single enantiomorphic form. Deviation (having the opposite form) could be found in a small number of chemical compounds, or certain organ or behavior but that variation strictly depends upon the genetic make up of the organism. From chemical level (molecular scale), biological systems show extreme stereospecificity in synthesis, uptake, sensing, metabolic processing. A living system usually deals with two enantiomers of same compound in a drastically different way. In biology, homochirality is a common property of [[Amino acid#Isomerism|amino acids]] and [[Monosaccharide#Open-chain stereoisomers|carbohydrates]]. The chiral [[Proteinogenic amino acid|protein-making amino acids]], which are translated through the ribosome from genetic coding, occur in the L form. However, D-amino acids are also found in nature. The monosaccharides (carbohydrate-units) are commonly found in D-configuration. DNA double helix is chiral (as any kind of [[Helix#Types|helix]] is chiral), and [[B-DNA|B-form of DNA]] shows a right-handed turn. {{multiple image |image1 = R-Limonene.png |width1 = 75 |caption1 = ''R''-(+)-Limonene found in orange |image2 = S-Limonene.png |width2 = 75 |caption2 = ''S''-(–)-Limonene found in lemon }} Sometimes, when two enantiomers of a compound found in organisms, they significantly differ in their taste, smell and other biological actions. For example, (+)-Limonene found in orange (causing its smell), and (–)-Limonene found in Lemons (causing its smell), show different smellsSolomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), Section 5.5 More about biological significance of chirality due to different biochemical interactions at human nose. (+)-Carvone is responsible for the smell of [[Caraway]] seed oil whereas (–)-carvone is responsible for smell of [[Spearmint]] oil.Solomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), review problem 5.14 [[File:Carvone-enantiomers1.jpg|thumb|S-(+)-Carvone occurs in Caraway seed oil, and R-(-)-Carvone occurs in spearmint|296x296px]] {{multiple image |image1 = Dextropropoxyphene structure.svg |width1 = 200 |caption1 = Dextropropoxyphene or Darvon, a painkiller |image2 = Levopropoxyphene structure.svg |width2 = 200 |caption2 = Levopropoxyphene or Novrad, an anticough agent }} Also, for artificial compounds, including medicines, in case of chiral drugs, the two enantiomers sometimes show remarkable difference in effect of their biological actions.{{Cite journal|last=Sanganyado|first=Edmond|last2=Lu|first2=Zhijiang|last3=Fu|first3=Qiuguo|last4=Schlenk|first4=Daniel|last5=Gan|first5=Jay|date=2017|title=Chiral pharmaceuticals: A review on their environmental occurrence and fate processes|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0043135417306565|journal=Water Research|volume=124|pages=527–542|doi=10.1016/j.watres.2017.08.003|issn=0043-1354|via=}} Darvon ([[Dextropropoxyphene]]) is a painkiller, whereas its enantiomer, Novrad ([[Levopropoxyphene]]) is an anti-cough agent. In case of [[Penicillamine]], the S-isomer used in treatment of primary chronic arthritis, Whereas the R-isomer has no therapeutic effect as well as being highly toxic.Solomon and Fryhles organic chemistry, Ed 10, Wiley (Students edition), Chapter 5 (Stereochemistry), section 5.11(chiral drugs) In some cases the less therapeutically active enantiomer can cause side effects. For example, S-naproxen is an analgesic but the R-isomer cause renal problems.{{Cite journal|last=Suzuki|first=Toshinari|last2=Kosugi|first2=Yuki|last3=Hosaka|first3=Mitsugu|last4=Nishimura|first4=Tetsuji|last5=Nakae|first5=Dai|date=2014-10-08|title=Occurrence and behavior of the chiral anti-inflammatory drug naproxen in an aquatic environment|url=https://setac.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/etc.2741|journal=Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry|language=en|volume=33|issue=12|pages=2671–2678|doi=10.1002/etc.2741|issn=0730-7268}} The naturally occurring plant form of alpha-tocopherol ([[vitamin E]]) is RRR-α-tocopherol whereas the synthetic form (all-racemic vitamin E, or dl-tocopherol) is equal parts of the stereoisomers RRR, RRS, RSS, SSS, RSR, SRS, SRR and SSR with progressively decreasing biological equivalency, so that 1.36 mg of dl-tocopherol is considered equivalent to 1.0 mg of d-tocopherol.{{cite journal |vauthors=Manolescu B, Atanasiu V, Cercasov C, Stoian I, Oprea E, Buşu C |title=So many options but one choice: the human body prefers alpha-tocopherol. A matter of stereochemistry |journal=J Med Life |volume=1 |issue=4 |pages=376–382 |date=2008 |pmid=20108516 |pmc=5654212 |doi= |url=}} [[File:DirkvdM natural spiral.jpg|thumb|A natural left-handed helix, made by a certain climber plant's [[tendril]]. |171x171px]] Macroscopic example of Chirality is found in plant kingdom, animal kingdom and all other groups of organism. A simple example is the coiling direction of any climber plants. It may be one of two possible type of helix. [[File:Neptunea - links&rechts gewonden.jpg|thumb|200px|Shells of two different species of sea snail: on the left is the normally sinistral (left-handed) shell of ''[[Neptunea angulata]]'', on the right is the normally dextral (right-handed) shell of ''[[Neptunea despecta]]'']] In anatomy, chirality is found in the imperfect mirror image symmetry of many kinds of animal bodies. Organisms such as [[gastropod]]s exhibit chirality in their coiled shells, resulting in an asymmetrical appearance. Over 90% of gastropod species {{cite journal | last1 = Schilthuizen | first1 = M. | last2 = Davison | first2 = A. | year = 2005 | title = The convoluted evolution of snail chirality | url = | journal = [[Naturwissenschaften]] | volume = 92 | issue = 11| pages = 504–515 | doi = 10.1007/s00114-05-0045-2| bibcode = 2005NW.....92..504S }} have ''dextral'' (right-handed) shells in their coiling, but a small minority of species and genera are virtually always ''sinistral'' (left-handed). A very few species (for example ''[[Amphidromus perversus]]''{{cite web|url=http://www.jaxshells.org/052ddr.htm|title=Amphidromus perversus (Linnaeus, 1758)|author=|date=|website=www.jaxshells.org|accessdate=23 March 2018}}) show an equal mixture of dextral and sinistral individuals. In humans, chirality (also referred to as ''handedness'' or ''laterality'') is an attribute of humans defined by their unequal distribution of [[fine motor skill]] between the left and right [[hands]]. An individual who is more [[Dexterity|dexterous]] with the right hand is called ''[[right-handed]]'', and one who is more skilled with the left is said to be ''[[left-handed]]''. Chirality is also seen in the study of [[facial asymmetry]]. In flatfish, the [[Summer flounder]] or fluke are left-eyed, while [[halibut]] are right-eyed. ==See also== * [[Asymmetry]] * [[Handedness]] * [[Metachirality]] * [[Orientation (mathematics)]] * [[Right-hand rule]] * [[Sinistral and dextral]] * [[Stereochemistry]] * [[Tendril perversion]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * The Handedness of the Universe by Roger A Hegstrom and Dilip K Kondepudi http://quantummechanics.ucsd.edu/ph87/ScientificAmerican/Sciam/Hegstrom_The_Handedness_of_the_universe.pdf {{Wiktionary}} {{Navbox stereochemistry}} [[Category:Biochemistry]] [[Category:Life]] [[Category:Origin of life]] [[Category:Stereochemistry]] [[Category:Chirality| ]] [[Category:Pharmacology]]

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Clotilde Tambroni | honorific_suffix = | image = Clotilde Tambroni.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | occupation = Classicist | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1758|6|29}} | birth_place = [[Bologna]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1817|6|2 |1758|6|29}} | death_place = Bologna | death_cause = | discipline = [[Classics]] | sub_discipline = Philology, Linguistics | alma_mater = | thesis_year = | workplaces = [[University of Bologna]] | awards = }} '''Clotilde Tambroni''' (29 June 1758 – 2 June 1817), was an Italian [[philologist]], [[linguist]] and [[poet]]. She was a [[professor]] in the [[Greek language]] at the [[University of Bologna]] in 1793–1798, and a professor in Greek and [[literature]] in 1800–1808.<ref name=":0">G. Melzi, Dizionario di opere anonime e pseudonime di scrittori italiani, Pirola, Milano 1848, pp 332</ref> She succeeded in achieving institutional recognition by a university long before women in many parts of the world could even attend university.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women Classical Scholars: Unsealing the Fountain from the Renaissance to Jacqueline de Romilly|last=Wiles|first=R|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2017|isbn=0198725205|location=Oxford|pages=17–18}}</ref> As well as her native Italian, she was also fluent in French, English and Spanish.<ref name=":1" />
== Career == In 1790, Clothilde Tambroni was invited into the Accademia degli Inestricati, and then in 1792 also admitted to the [[Accademia degli Arcadi]], under the pseudonym of ''Doriclea Sicionia.''<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.storiaememoriadibologna.it/tambroni-clotilde-481331-persona|title=Tambroni Clotilde - Storia e memoria di bologna|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 June 2017}}</ref> Despite having had no opportunity to obtain an academic degree, on 23 November 1793 she was assigned the Chair of Greek Language.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.homolaicus.com/uomo-donna/donne_famose.htm|title=Donne famose di Bologna|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 June 2017}}</ref>
In 1798, after having lost her position for refusing to swear her loyalty to the new Cisalpine government, she worked in Spain as a researcher alongside her father, Emanuele Aponte, and was accepted into the l’Accademia Reale di Madrid.<ref name=":1" />
Notwithstanding her political ideas, in September 1799 she was restored to the Accademia degli Inestricati as Chair of Greek Language and Literature, and in 1804 was granted a large pay rise.<ref name=":1" />
She retired early, citing reasons of ill-health although the Greek Chair was to be abolished under the Napoleonic reforms, which privileged the teaching of science to the detriment of literary studies, although Tambroni herself said at her inaugural speech on 11 January 1806, science and literature had always been linked and notable scientists and humanists both produced by the Bolognese institution.<ref name=":1" />
[[Adamo Tadolini]] sculpted her marble bust, supervised by [[Canova]] who was a friend of the Tambroni family.<ref>G. Tambroni, Intorno la vita di Antonio Canova, Salviucci, Roma 1823.</ref> She received a lengthy dedication by [[Ireneo Affò]], in his volume ''[https://archive.org/stream/bub_gb_59YNk7RX7moC/bub_gb_59YNk7RX7moC_djvu.txt Ragionamento Del Padre].''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.royalacademy.org.uk/art-artists/name/clotilde-tambroni|title=Clothilde Tambroni - Artists - Royal Academy of Arts|last=|first=|date=|website=Royal Academy of Arts|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 December 2017}}</ref>
== Major works == * ''Per le faustissime nozze del nobil uomo il signor conte Niccolo Fava Ghisilieri colla nobil donna la signora Gaetana Marescotti Berselli. Versi'', co' tipi Bodoniani, Parma 1792. * ''Pel felice parto della nobil donna signora contessa Susanna Jenisson Walworth Spencer. Ode greco-italiana'', Stamp. S. Tommaso d'Aquino, Bologna 1792. * ''Per la ricuperata salute dell'em.mo e rev.mo signor cardinale d. Andrea Gioannetti degnissimo arcivescovo di Bologna. Ode pindarica'', stamp. S. Tommaso d'Aquino, Bologna 1793. * ''Al nobile ed eccelso signor conte senatore Ferdinando Marescalchi Fava pel quinto solenne suo ingresso al gonfalonierato di giustizia della città e popolo di Bologna. Ode saffica greca'', co' tipi Bodoniani, Parma 1794. * ''In onore del celebre tipografo Giambattista Bodoni. Elegia greca'', Tip. Reale Bodoni, Parma 1795. * ''In lode del feld-maresciallo conte di Clairfait. Ode'', Stamp. S. Tommaso d'Aquino, Bologna 1796.
== Published volumes of her letters == * ''Lettere inedite di Clotilde Tambroni'', a cura di M.F. Sacchi, Tip. Agnelli, Milano 1804. * ''Alcune lettere della celebre grecista Clotilde Tambroni'', a cura di F. Raffaello, Tip. Corradetti, San Severino Marche 1870. * ''Lettere di quattro gentildonne bolognesi'', a cura di S. Battistini e C. Ricci, Tip. Monti, Bologna 1883.

{{Infobox Website | name = Colnect Collectors Club Community | logo = Colnect Logo.png | url = http://colnect.com/ | type = Online collectible item catalogs and personal collection management | language = 62 languages | registration = free registration is optional | owner = Colnect, private | author = Amir Wald | launched = 28th April, 2002 | current status = Active }}
'''Colnect Collectors Club Community''', is a [[website]] containing [[wiki]]-like [[collectable]]s catalogs. It allows collectors to manage their personal [[collecting|collection]] using these catalogs and automatically match their swap/wish-lists with those of other collectors. Colnect provides a marketplace dedicated to buying and selling collectibles. Colnect's [[phone cards]] catalog is the biggest in the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://it.themarker.com/tmit/article/3471 |title=TechNation- מדור הטכונולוגיה וההייטק של דה מרקר - TheMarker |work=TheMarker |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090130111818/http://it.themarker.com/tmit/article/3471 |archivedate=2009-01-30 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.israel-on-blog.com/colnects-collectible-phone-cards-listing-has-just-passed-100000/ Article from "Israel on Blog"]</ref>
== History == Colnect was founded in 2002 as ''Islands Phonecards Database'' with the aim to create a catalog of all phonecards. Since autumn 2008, [[Postage stamp|stamps]] and [[coins]] are supported in addition to [[phone cards]]. In the mean time, 38<ref>{{cite web|url=http://colnect.com/en/main/categories|title=Colnect, connecting collectors: Colnect|work=colnect.com}}</ref> types of collectables are represented. Here is an overview of selected collectibles:

(''Last Updated: 19 September 2018'', the figures in the table above were rounded down)
== Features == The collectables catalogs on Colnect are created by collectors using the site. New items are added by contributors and verified by volunteering editors. Though any collector may add their comments on a catalog item, actual changes are done only by site-trusted editors. All users can see the catalog information (issue dates, print runs, pictures, etc.). Registered users can additionally manage their personal collection by marking each item as belonging to their collection, swap list or wish list while browsing through the catalogs. These users automatically can match their swap list with a wish list of another user and vice versa.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2009/06/14/colnect-is-a-no-frills-collectibles-marketplace-and-wiki-someone-wake-up-david-cowan/|title=Colnect Is A No-Frills Collectibles Marketplace And Wiki. Someone Wake Up David Cowan!|author=Roi Carthy|publisher=AOL|work=TechCrunch}}</ref> Users can purchase a Premium membership with additional features. Contributors get it for free. Premium members can download any list with collectables and open it as a [[spreadsheet]].
Colnect provides a marketplace for collectibles. It is publicly available since December 27, 2017. Sales on the marketplace are connected to the centralized catalogs. Sellers can post items for sale directly from the catalog and buyers can view information about a collectible on the item's page.
== Statistics == The site reports it caters for collectors from 113<ref>{{cite web|url=http://colnect.com/en/collectors/countries|title=Collectors : Countries List [Collectibles: All]|work=colnect.com}}</ref> countries. Hundreds of them are helping the site voluntarily, including the translators who translate Colnect into 62 languages.
As of 2018 Colnect lists 435 Chinese transportation tickets, which are issued by 147 different Chinese companies.<ref>Chinese Money Matters (The [[British Museum]]) - [https://chinesemoneymatters.wordpress.com/2018/06/27/49-chinese-transportation-tokens-and-tickets/ 49. Chinese transportation tokens and tickets]. Retrieved: 02 July 2018.</ref>
== Rewards == On April 25, 2009 Colnect was announced as the winner in the European Startup 2.0 competition, out of about 200 competing companies and 11 finalists.<ref>[http://nonickconference.com/2009/04/26/colnect-wins-this-years-startup-20/ Colnect wins Startup2.0] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429033415/http://nonickconference.com/2009/04/26/colnect-wins-this-years-startup-20/ |date=2009-04-29 }}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rKj120m7HVc|title=Amir Wald|date=11 November 2009|work=YouTube}}</ref>
On December 31, 2009 Colnect was a close runner up on the TechAviv Peer Awards startup companies competition. It has lost to 5min by a single vote.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000526923&fid=2 TechAviv Peer Awards]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vccafe.com/2009/12/30/5min-wins-top-spot-in-techavivs-peer-awards/|title=5min Wins Top Spot in TechAviv’s Peer Awards|work=VC Cafe}}</ref>

{{for|the Israeli judge|Edmond Levy (judge)}} '''Edmond Lévy''' (born 1934) is a French [[classical history|classical historian]].
==Biography==
Originally a pupil of [[École normale supérieure]] (promotion 1956), an aggregate of letters, he was a pupil of [[École française d'Athènes]], a school where the French language is educated to students mainly from France in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. He is a specialist in Greek history, he is a retired professor at Marc-Bloch University in [[Strasbourg]], [[France]]. He directs the ''Ktèma'' review.
==Works==
* ''Athènes devant la défaite de 404. Histoire d'une crise idéologique'', De Boccard, 1976 * ''La femme dans les sociétés antiques'', [[University of Strasbourg]], 1983 * ''Le système palatial en Orient, en Grèce et à Rome'', De Boccard, 1987 * ''La Grèce au Ve siècle, de Clisthène à Socrate'', Seuil, 1995 * ''La codification des lois dans l'Antiquité'', De Boccard, 2000 * ''Sparte. Histoire politique et sociale jusqu'à la conquête romaine'', Seuil, 2003
==External links== *In French: **https://web.archive.org/web/20051014161612/http://www.umr7044.cnrs.fr/ANNUAIRE/titulaires/EdmondLevy.html **https://web.archive.org/web/20060322095917/http://www.fnac.com/199331/rcwwwa/La-Grece-au-Veme-siecle-De-Clisthene-a-Socrate-Nouvelle-histoire-de-l-Antiquite
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Levy, Edmund}} [[Category:20th-century French historians]] [[Category:Historians of antiquity]] [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:Members of the French School at Athens]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{BLP sources|date=July 2010}} '''Gerald John Pillay''' [[FRSA]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (born 21 December 1953) is a South African historian and the present [[Vice Chancellor]] & Rector of [[Liverpool Hope University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article495258.ece|title=UK varsity to honour Rajmohan Gandhi|date=1 July 2010|work=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=6 July 2010}}</ref>
==Career== Born in [[Natal Province|Natal]] in [[South Africa]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/career_and_jobs/article4059740.ece|title=Working Relationship: Professor Gerald Pillay...|date=3 June 2008|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=6 July 2010 | location=London | first=Rosalind | last=Renshaw}}</ref> Pillay was awarded a BA, a BD (with Distinction) and Doctor of Theology from the [[University of Durban-Westville]] and a further DPhil in Philosophical Theology from [[Rhodes University]]. On 1 September 2003, Pillay was appointed Rector & Chief Executive of Liverpool Hope University. In 2005, he was elected a Life Fellow of the [[Royal Society of the Arts]] (FRSA). He lived in [[New Zealand]] with his family for many years of his life before moving to the UK.
After lecturing at the [[University of Durban-Westville]], he became Professor of Ecclesiastical History at the [[University of South Africa]] in 1988, a post he held for eight years. During this period, he was also Guest Professor at [[North Western University]], Illinois; Research Fellow at [[Princeton University]]; Guest Professor at Rhodes University and Visiting Professor at the Graduate School at the [[Associated Mennonite Biblical Seminary]] (AMBS), Indiana, USA.
In 1997, he became Foundation Professor at the [[University of Otago]], New Zealand. In 1998, he became Executive Head of the School of Liberal Arts within that University.
Pillay has served on editorial boards of two international journals (Studia Historiae Ecclesiasticae and Verbum et Ecclesia), has presented papers at numerous international conferences and has served on various public and educational bodies. He has been involved in recent research and lecturing in Cambridge, Oxford, Pretoria, California, Canada and Munich.
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pillay, Gerald J}} [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Merseyside]] [[Category:People from KwaZulu-Natal]] [[Category:Rhodes University alumni]] [[Category:Academics of Liverpool Hope University]] [[Category:South African historians]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Arts]] [[Category:University of Durban-Westville alumni]] [[Category:University of South Africa academics]] [[Category:University of Otago faculty]]

[[Image:Jacana jacana Niagara Falls Aviary.jpg|thumb|210px|Female [[wattled jacana]]s often carry out infanticide.]] Within the field of [[social evolution]], '''Hamiltonian spite''' is a term for behaviours occurring among conspecifics that have a cost for the actor and a negative impact upon the recipient.
==Theories on altruism and spitefulness==
[[W. D. Hamilton]] published an influential paper on [[altruism]] in 1964 to explain why genetic kin tend to help each other.<ref>Hamilton WD 1964. The genetical evolution of social behaviour. Part I and II. Journal of Theoretical Biology 7: 1–16 and 17–52.</ref> He argued that genetically related individuals are likely to carry the copies of the same [[alleles]]; thus, helping kin may ensure that copies of the actors' alleles pass onto next generations of both the recipient and the actor.
While this became a widely accepted idea, it was less noted that Hamilton published a later paper that modified this view.<ref>Hamilton WD 1970. Selfish and spiteful behaviour in an evolutionary model. Nature 228: 1218–20.</ref> This paper argues that by measuring the genetic relatedness between any two (randomly chosen) individuals of a population several times, we can identify an average level of relatedness. Theoretical models predict that (1) it is adaptive for an individual to be altruistic to any other individuals that are more closely related to it than this average level, and also that (2) it is adaptive for an individual to be spiteful against any other individuals that are less closely related to it than this average level. The indirect adaptive benefits of such acts can surpass certain costs of the act (either helpful or harmful) itself. Hamilton mentioned birds and fishes exhibiting [[Infanticide (zoology)|infanticide]] (more specifically: ovicide) as examples for such behaviours.
Briefly, an individual can increase the chance of its genetic alleles to be passed to the next generations either by helping those that are more closely related, or by harming those that are less closely related than relationship by chance.<ref>Vickery WL, Brown JS, FitzGerald GJ 2003. Spite: altruism’s evil twin. Oikos, 102, 413–16.</ref><ref>Foster KR, Wenseleers T, Ratnieks FLW 2001. Spite: Hamilton’s unproven theory. Annales Zoologici Fennici 38: 229–38.</ref>
==Doubts about the adaptive nature of spiteful behaviour==
Though altruism and spitefulness appear to be two sides of the same coin, the latter is less accepted among evolutionary biologists.
First, unlike the case with the beneficiary of an altruistic act, targets of aggression are likely to act in revenge: bites will provoke bites. Thus harming non-kin may be more costly than helping kins.
Second, presuming a [[Panmixia|panmictic population]], the vast majority of pairs of individuals exhibit a roughly average level of relatedness. For a given individual, the majority of others are not worth helping or harming. While it is easy to identify the few most closely related ones (see: [[kin recognition]]), it is hard to identify the most genetically distant ones.
Most terrestrial [[vertebrates]] exhibit a certain degree of site fidelity, so levels of kinship tend to correlate negatively with spatial distance. While this may provide some cues to identify the least related individuals, it may also ensure that non-kin rarely if ever meet each other.
==Spiteful behaviour in animals== ===Infanticide===
Many animal species exhibit infanticide, i.e. adults tend to kill the eggs or the offspring of conspecifics, even if they do not feed on them (in the absence of [[cannibalism]]).<ref>van Schaik CP, Janson CH (eds.) 2000. Infanticide by males and its implications. Cambridge, UK: Cambridge Univ Press.</ref> This form of spitefulness is relatively free from the threat of revenge – provided that the parents and relatives of the target are either weak or far away. Infanticide may not be a form of spite as in many cases the loss of offspring to the female brings it back into estrous providing a mating advantage to an infanticidal male. This is seen in lions. <ref>Van Schaik, C. P., & Janson, C. H. (Eds.). (2000). Infanticide by males and its implications. Cambridge University Press.</ref> [[Image:Meles meles MHNT.jpg|thumb|210px|When infected by tuberculosis, badgers emigrate from their natal group.]]
===Aggression by means of pathogens===
An individual carrying a long-lasting infection of virulent pathogens may benefit from (1) channelling the flow of pathogens from its own body away from its kin and (2) directing them toward non-kin conspecifics. The adaptive nature of this behaviour has been supported by the analysis of theoretical models <ref>[http://www.zoologia.hu/list/transmission.pdf Rózsa L 1999. Influencing random transmission is a neutral character in hosts. Journal of Parasitology, 85, 1032–35.]</ref><ref>[http://webpages.fc.ul.pt/~fadionisio/Selfish_and_Spiteful_behaviour_parasites_pathogens2007.pdf Dionisio F 2007. Selfish and spiteful behaviour through parasites and pathogens. Evolutionary Ecology Research, 9: 1199-1210]</ref> and also by the analyses of the behavioural repertoire of different animal species.<ref>[http://www.zoologia.hu/list/spite.pdf Rózsa L 2000. Spite, xenophobia, and collaboration between hosts and parasites. Oikos 91: 396–400.]</ref> Thus, [[tuberculosis]]-infected [[European badger]]s and [[rabies]]-infected [[dog]]s equally tend to emigrate from their natal ranges before starting to distribute the pathogens. Similarly, wild herds of [[Asian elephants]] tend to defecate into drinkwater holes apparently to keep rival herds away.<ref>[http://www.ias.ac.in/currsci/oct102005/1184.pdf Jog M, Watve M 2005. Role of parasites and commensals in shaping host behaviour. Current Science 89: 1184–91]</ref>
[[Image:Lüen Kindermord.jpg|thumb|330px|Wartime infanticide is a characteristic aspect of human aggression.]]
==Spiteful behaviour in humans== ===Wartime infanticide===
Throughout human history, [[war]] often emerges as a costly form of aggression typically targeting the non-kin enemy. Naturally, most wars appear to be motivated by potential benefits other than the genetic. Nevertheless, the widespread occurrence of [[rape]]{{citation needed|reason=Don't the following sentences contradict this?|date=August 2013}} and [[infanticide]] during periods of war indicates Hamiltonian elements as well. Infanticide is a biologically spiteful action in that it costs the killer time and energy, and opens the killer to the threat of revenge, without any direct compensating benefits.{{citation needed|reason=While such a behavior *may* be spiteful, it does not match the definition of Hamiltonian spite we give|date=August 2013}} Rape, by contrast, is not, in the strict definition of the word, biologically spiteful as it is likely to have a direct fitness increase on the rapist (by increasing his number of direct descendants in the next generation, should the victim fall pregnant).
===Economy===
It was recently suggested that spiteful motivations may also play a role in economic decisions.<ref>Boari M 2007. The ethics of rationality. Elucidations in the theoretical foundations of economics by relation to ethics. In: Vranceanu R, Djelic M-L, editors. Moral foundations of management knowledge. Cheltenham, UK: Edward Elgar Publications; p. 107–33.</ref>
===Aggression by means of pathogens===
{{See also|McNeill's law}}
Moreover, another paper argues that the motivation for biological aggression – i.e. using pathogens as weapons – is an inherent and common aspect of the human behavioural repertoire.<ref>[http://www.zoologia.hu/list/motivation.pdf Rózsa L 2009. The motivation for biological aggression is an inherent and common aspect of the human behavioural repertoire. Medical Hypotheses 72: 217–19.]</ref> This argument contradicts the widespread belief that biological weapons are rare and aberrant tools of warfare and it is supported by the following observations: * the use of pathogen weapons predates the scientific understanding of infections and epidemics; * attempts of biological aggression are easy to hide and to overlook, thus it appears to be underrepresented in written history; * it is a frequent component of our expectations concerning the likely behaviour of an enemy; * it is also a frequent component of threats (see e.g. ''white powder letters''); * several languages appear to bear linguistic references to our motivation for biological aggression in profanity. * given that wartime epidemics tend to kill people at a rate exceeding (or at least comparable to) that of traditional weapons, all wars fought in recorded history incorporated an implicit element of aggression by biological means.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{sociobiology}} {{evolutionary psychology}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hamiltonian Spite}} [[Category:Evolutionary psychology]] [[Category:Human behavior]] [[Category:Theories of history]] [[Category:Biological warfare]]

revision.text:
'''Hillel Cohen-Bar''' (born in Jerusalem, 5 October 1961) is an [[Israel]]i scholar who studies and writes about Jewish-Arab relations in Palestine/Israel. He is an associated professor at the Department of Islam and Middle East Studies at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, and the head of the Cherrick Center for the Study of Zionism and the State of Israel at that university.
Cohen is especially familiar with [[east Jerusalem]], the topic of his book, ''Kikar Hashuk Reka'' (The Marketplace is Empty or: The Rise and Fall of Arab Jeruslaem), because of the years he spent as a correspondent for east Jerusalem affairs for the Israeli weekly ''[[Kol Ha'ir]]''. He published extensively on the Palestinian internal refugees and on the 1948 war. Two of his books deal with Palestinian collaborators and the Israeli security agencies, using methodology that can be described as history-from-below. The [[Jerusalem Post]] calls his books "an accessible mixture of academic research and vivid journalistic reporting. Cohen manages to show empathy when relating human issues, but maintains a professional distance regarding events."<ref>{{cite web|title=Reluctant Residents|author=Cidor, Peggy|publisher=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=2007-10-10|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1191257269870&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull|accessdate=2008-10-31}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
He first became known in other countries in 2008 when his book ''[[Army of Shadows, Palestinian Collaboration with Zionism, 1917-1948]]'' was published with the University of California Press. His book ''Good Arabs: The Israeli Security Services and the Israeli Arabs'' was published with the same press. His latest book ''[[Year Zero of the Arab-Israeli Conflict]]'' was published by Brandeis University Press, 2015.
==Bibliography== *''The Present Absentee: Palestinian Refugees in Israel Since 1948'' (Hebrew, Arabic) *''Good Arabs: The Israeli Security Services and the Israeli Arabs ערבים טובים'' (Hebrew 2006, English 2010) *''[[Army of Shadows, Palestinian Collaboration with Zionism, 1917–1948]]'' (2004 Hebrew, 2008 English) *''The Rise and Fall of Arab Jerusalem'' (2007 Hebrew, 2011 English) *''Year Zero of the Arab-Israeli Conflict 1929 תרפ"ט שנת האפס בסכסוך היהודי ערבי '' (Hebrew 2013, 2015 English)
==Notes== {{reflist}} {{New Historians}}

{{more footnotes|date=January 2013}} '''Janko Pleterski''' (1 February 1923 – 8 June 2018)<ref>http://www.delo.si/novice/slovenija/poslovil-se-je-janko-pleterski-59110.html</ref> was a [[Slovenia]]n [[historian]], [[politician]] and [[diplomat]].
He was born in [[Maribor]], Slovenia, then part of the [[Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]]. He attended high school in [[Ljubljana]]. In August 1941, he was arrested by the [[Fascist]] authorities of the [[Kingdom of Italy (1861-1946)|Italian]]-occupied [[Province of Ljubljana]] and imprisoned in [[Alessandria]], [[Italy]]. After the [[Italian armistice]] in September 1943, he returned to Ljubljana. In July 1944, he joined the [[Yugoslav partisans|partisan resistance]]. After the end of [[World War II]], he worked at the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] foreign ministry in [[Belgrade]] as an expert on border issues with Italy and [[Austria]]. In 1953, he became a researcher at the [[Institute for Ethnic Studies]] in Ljubljana. In 1963, he obtained a PhD in modern history at the [[University of Ljubljana]]. Between 1970 and 1982, he taught modern political history of [[Slovenes]] and [[South Slavs]] at the same university. Between 1988 and 1990, he was member of the Presidential Council of the [[Socialist Republic of Slovenia]], as part of the reformist circle of the [[Communist Party of Slovenia]] around [[Milan Kučan]] and [[Janez Stanovnik]] who negotiated with the [[DEMOS coalition|opposition]] a gradual democratisation of Slovenia. In 1989, he became a member of the [[Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts]].
Pleterski wrote extensively on the Slovene history of late 19th and early 20th century, with an emphasis on the history of [[Carinthian Slovenes]], and on the relations between Slovenes and other Yugoslav peoples.
He was the father of the historian and archeologist [[Andrej Pleterski]].
== References == <references /> *[http://www.sazu.si/o-sazu/clani/janko-pleterski.html Biography on the webpage of the Slovenian Academy of Sciences and Arts]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox academic |honorific_prefix=Professor |name=Jennifer Ingleheart |image=Professor Jennifer Ingleheart.jpg |caption=Professor Jennifer Ingleheart |birth_date= |alma_mater=[[Wadham College, Oxford]] |thesis_title=A commentary on Ovid Tristia 2.1-262 |doctoral_advisor=[[Stephen Heyworth]], [[Adrian Hollis]] |discipline=[[Classics]] |sub_discipline={{hlist|[[Latin Literature]]|[[Classical reception studies]]}} |workplaces=[[University of Durham]] |notable_works=''A Commentary on Ovid, Tristia, Book 2''
''Ancient Rome and the Construction of Modern Homosexual Identities'' }} '''Jennifer Ingleheart''' is a British classical scholar, who is known for her work on [[Ovid]], [[Classical reception studies|Classical reception]], and the influence of Rome on the modern understanding of [[homosexuality]]. She is [[Professor (highest academic rank)|Professor]] of Latin at the [[University of Durham]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/classics/staff/?id=1147|title=Prof. J Ingleheart - Durham University|website=www.dur.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/classical.tradition/people/jenniferinglehea/|title=Durham Centre for Classical Reception : Dr Jennifer Ingleheart - Durham University|website=www.dur.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} == Career == Ingleheart was educated at [[Bradford Girls' Grammar School]] and [[Wadham College, Oxford]]. Ingleheart read [[Literae Humaniores]] at [[Wadham College, Oxford|Wadham College]], and went on to complete her M.St. and D.Phil. there in 2004 on Ovid's ''[[Tristia]]'',{{Cite thesis|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|title=A commentary on Ovid Tristia 2.1-262|date=2004|publisher=Thesis DPhil--University of Oxford, Humanities Division ; Faculty of Literae Humaniores ; Wadham College|url=http://solo.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/display.do?tabs=detailsTab&ct=display&fn=search&doc=oxfaleph019851090&indx=4&recIds=oxfaleph019851090&recIdxs=3&elementId=3&renderMode=poppedOut&displayMode=full&frbrVersion=2&frbg=&vl(254947567UI0)=any&&dscnt=0&vl(1UIStartWith0)=contains&scp.scps=scope:(OX)&tb=t&vid=OXVU1&mode=Basic&vl(516065169UI1)=all_items&srt=rank&tab=local&dum=true&vl(freeText0)=Ingleheart,%20J&dstmp=1530716994774}} which was published in 2010. After teaching at [[Marlboro College]], [[Vermont]], [[Swansea University]], and [[Keble College, Oxford|Keble]] and [[Wadham College, Oxford|Wadham]] Colleges in [[Oxford]], she joined [[Durham University]] as a lecturer in 2004 before becoming senior lecturer in 2012, associate professor and then [[Professor (highest academic rank)|Professor]] of Latin.{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/two-thousand-years-of-solitude-9780199603848?cc=us&lang=en&#|title=Two Thousand Years of Solitude: Exile After Ovid|date=2011-12-17|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199603848|series=Classical Presences|location=Oxford, New York}} Ingleheart is now head of the Department of Classics and Ancient History.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/university.calendar/volumei/heads_of_department/|title=University Calendar : Heads of Department - Durham University|website=www.dur.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} Ingleheart has spoken frequently about her work on how modern cultures have responded to the phenomenon of Roman homosexuality, and the role which ancient Rome has played in modern ideas about sexuality.{{Cite web|url=http://www.exeter.ac.uk/news/events/details/index.php?event=4153|title=University of Exeter|last=Robinson|first=Debbie|website=www.exeter.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.acrsn.org/conferences_archive.html|title=Australian Classical Reception Studies Network|website=www.acrsn.org|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://wcc-uk.blogs.sas.ac.uk/2017/12/03/event-lgbt-classics-teaching-research-activism/|title=Event – LGBT+ Classics: Teaching, Research, Activism|date=2017-12-03|work=WCC-UK|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.ntnu.edu/hethompo/conferences-events|title=Conferences and events - The heterosexual tradition of homoerotic poetics|last=Fossen|first=Christian|website=www.ntnu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} She ran a major [[British Academy]] funded conference in 2012, ''Romosexuality,'' on the subject which has shed considerable light on the differences between Roman and Greek conceptions of homosexuality, and differences from modern conceptions.{{Cite web|url=https://romosexuality.wordpress.com/|title=International Conference at Durham, 16th-18th April 2012.|website=International Conference at Durham, 16th-18th April 2012.|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/carry-on-loving-the-roman-way/419679.article|title=Carry on loving, the Roman way|date=2012-04-19|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en}} Previously most work on classical homosexuality focused on Greek homosexuality and its modern reception, but Ingleheart's work has facilitated new research and interest in the Roman experience.{{Cite web|url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/17059/|title=Romosexuality : Rome, homosexuality, and reception.|last=Jennifer|first=Ingleheart,|date=2015-10-01|website=dro.dur.ac.uk|access-date=2018-07-04}} The modern reception of Roman homosexuality in particular has lead to Ingleheart's current work on, and translation of, [[A. E. Housman|AE Housman's]] ''Praefunda,'' a study of classical sexuality in Latin.{{Cite web|url=https://www2.mmu.ac.uk/artshumanities/rah/events/detail/index.php?id=7481|title=Detail, Manchester Metropolitan University|last=University|first=Manchester Metropolitan|website=www2.mmu.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.harts.online/lecture-for-lgbt-history-month-professor-jennifer-ingleheart-21st-feb/|title=Lecture for LGBT History Month: Professor Jennifer Ingleheart, 21st Feb - HARTS.ONLINE News|date=2018-02-15|work=HARTS.ONLINE News|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en-GB}} == Television == * ''Ovid: The Poet and the Emperor'' [[BBC]] 4 (2017 documentary presented by [[Michael Wood (historian)|Michael Wood]]){{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b09g0l2q|title=Ovid: The Poet and the Emperor - BBC Four|website=BBC|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-07-04}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/classics/events/?id=32877&itemno=32877|title=Jennifer Ingleheart on BBCFour - Durham University|website=www.dur.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} == Select publications == * ''Masculine Plural: Queer Classics, Sex, and Education'' (Oxford University Press 2018){{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/masculine-plural-9780198819677?cc=au&lang=en|title=Masculine Plural: Queer Classics, Sex, and Education|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2018-09-13|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198819677|series=Classical Presences|location=Oxford, New York}} * ''Ancient Rome and the Construction of Modern Homosexual Identities'' (Oxford University Press 2015){{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2015-10-01|title=Introduction: Romosexuality: Rome, Homosexuality, and Reception|url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/view/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199689729.001.0001/acprof-9780199689729-chapter-1|language=en-US|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199689729.001.0001/acprof-9780199689729-chapter-1}}{{Cite journal|last=Verstraete|first=Beert C.|date=2016|title=Review of: Ancient Rome and the Construction of Modern Homosexual Identities. Classical presences|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2016/2016-12-15.html|journal=Bryn Mawr Classical Review|volume=|pages=|issn=1055-7660|via=}} *“Ovid's ''scripta puella'': Perilla as poetic and political fiction in ''Tristia'' 3.71.” ''The Classical Quarterly'' 62, no. 1 (2012): 227–41.{{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2012|title=OVID'S SCRIPTA PUELLA: PERILLA AS POETIC AND POLITICAL FICTION IN TRISTIA 3.711|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/classical-quarterly/article/ovids-scripta-puella-perilla-as-poetic-and-political-fiction-in-tristia-3711/566593600D0509B3FDAB4A1F70C3408B|journal=The Classical Quarterly|language=en|volume=62|issue=1|pages=227–241|doi=10.1017/S0009838811000504|issn=1471-6844|via=}} * (ed.) ''Two Thousand Years of Solitude: Exile After Ovid'' (Oxford University Press 2011){{Cite news|url=https://rogueclassicism.com/2012/11/22/cj-online-review-ingleheart-two-thousand-years-of-solitude/|title=CJ Online Review: Ingleheart, Two Thousand Years of Solitude|date=2012-11-22|work=rogueclassicism|access-date=2018-07-04|language=en-US}} * ''A Commentary on Ovid,'' Tristia'', Book 2'' (Oxford University Press 2010){{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/646393951|title=A commentary on Ovid, Tristia, book 2|last=Jennifer.|first=Ingleheart,|date=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199590421|location=Oxford|oclc=646393951}} *“Propertius 4.10 and the end of the Aeneid: Augustus, the ''spolia opima'' and the right to remain silent.” ''Greece and Rome'' 54, no. 1 (2007): 61–81.{{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2007|title=PROPERTIUS 4.10 AND THE END OF THE AENEID: AUGUSTUS, THE SPOLIA OPIMA AND THE RIGHT TO REMAIN SILENT|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/greece-and-rome/article/propertius-410-and-the-end-of-the-aeneid-augustus-the-spolia-opima-and-the-right-to-remain-silent/D7618B19AFD45A512B972E443772F623|journal=Greece & Rome|language=en|volume=54|issue=1|pages=61–81|doi=10.1017/S0017383507000046|issn=1477-4550|via=}} *"What the Poet Saw: Ovid, the Error and the Theme of Sight in Tristia 2." ''Materiali E Discussioni per L'analisi Dei Testi Classici'', no. 56 (2006): 63-86.{{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2006|title=What the Poet Saw: Ovid, the Error and the Theme of Sight in Tristia 2|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/40236287|journal=Materiali e discussioni per l'analisi dei testi classici|issue=56|pages=63–86}} *“Ovid ''Tristia'' 1.2: High Drama on the High Seas.” ''Greece and Rome'' 53, no. 1 (2006): 73–91.{{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=Jennifer|date=2006|title=OVID, TRISTIA 1.2: HIGH DRAMA ON THE HIGH SEAS|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/greece-and-rome/article/ovid-tristia-12-high-drama-on-the-high-seas/C7B5F2B9386D912AFDB67DE2F529F4FC|journal=Greece & Rome|language=en|volume=53|issue=1|pages=73–91|doi=10.1017/S0017383506000052|issn=1477-4550|via=}} *"Catullus 2 And 3: A programmatic pair of Sapphic epigrams?" ''Mnemosyne'' 56, no. 5 (2003): 551-65.{{Cite journal|last=Ingleheart|first=J.|date=2003-09-01|title=CATULLUS 2 AND 3: A PROGRAMMATIC PAIR OF SAPPHIC EPIGRAMS?|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/156852503770735952|journal=Mnemosyne|language=en|volume=56|issue=5|pages=551–565|doi=10.1163/156852503770735952|issn=1568-525X}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[https://www.dur.ac.uk/classics/staff/?id=1147 University of Durham staff page] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ingleheart, Jennifer}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:English classical scholars]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Academics of Durham University]] [[Category:Women classical scholars]] [[Category:People educated at Bradford Girls' Grammar School]] [[Category:Alumni of Wadham College, Oxford]]

{{History of Japan |image=Shoso-in.jpg |caption=[[Shōsōin]]}} {{nihongo|'''Kanshō'''|寛正}} was a {{nihongo|[[Japanese era name]]|年号,| ''nengō'',| lit. "year name"}} after ''[[Chōroku]]'' and before ''[[Bunshō]].'' This period spanned from December 1460 through February 1466.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "''Kanshō''" in [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA478&dq= ''Japan encyclopedia'', p. 478;] n.b., Louis-Frédéric is pseudonym of Louis-Frédéric Nussbaum, ''see'' [http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 Deutsche Nationalbibliothek Authority File] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120524174828/http://dispatch.opac.ddb.de/DB=4.1/PPN?PPN=128842709 |date=2012-05-24 }}. The reigning emperors were {{nihongo|[[Emperor Go-Hanazono of Japan|Go-Hanazono]]''-tennō''|後花園天皇}} and {{nihongo|[[Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado of Japan|Go-Tsuchimikado]]''-tennō''|後土御門天皇}}.Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP9&dq=nipon+o+dai+itsi+ran#PRA1-PA331,M1 ''Annales des empereurs du japon'', pp. 331]-351. ==Change of era== * '''1460''' {{nihongo|''Kanshō gannen''|寛正元年}}: The era name was changed to mark an event or a number of events. The old era ended and a new one commenced in ''Chōroku'' 4. ==Events of the ''Kanshō'' era== * '''1460''' (''Kanshō 1, 9th month''): [[Wakae Castle]] in [[Kawachi Province]] was destroyed when {{nihongo|Hatakeyama Yoshinari|畠山 義就||1437-21 January 1491}} was forced out of it.Titsingh, [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&&pg=PA350#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 350]; Ramirez-Christensen, Experanza U. (1994). [https://books.google.com/books?id=dCpC9h1tCVcC&pg=PA28&lpg=PA28&dq= ''Heart's flower: the life and poetry of Shinkei,'' p. 28]. * '''August 21, 1464''' (''Kanshō 5, 19th day of the 7th month''): Go-Hanazono resigned his throne in favor of his son, who would be known as Emperor Go-Tsuchimikado.Titsingh, [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP9&dq=nipon+o+dai+itsi+ran#PRA1-PA351,M1 p. 351.] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * Nussbaum, Louis Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). ''Japan Encyclopedia.'' Cambridge: [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-674-01753-5}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48943301/editions?editionsView=true&referer=br OCLC 48943301] * [[Richard Ponsonby-Fane|Ponsonby-Fane, Richard Arthur Brabazon]]. Ponsonby-Fane, Richard. (1956). [https://books.google.com/books?id=OpOdHQAACAAJ&dq=Kyoto:+The+Old+Capital+of+Japan,+794-1869&client=firefox-a ''Kyoto: The Old Capital of Japan, 794-1869.''] Kyoto: Ponsonby Memorial Society. [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/36644 OCLC 36644] * [[Isaac Titsingh|Titsingh, Isaac.]] (1834). ''[[Nihon Odai Ichiran]]''; ou, [https://books.google.com/books?id=18oNAAAAIAAJ&dq=nipon+o+dai+itsi+ran ''Annales des empereurs du Japon.''] Paris: Royal Asiatic Society, Oriental Translation Fund of Great Britain and Ireland. [http://www.worldcat.org/title/nipon-o-dai-itsi-ran-ou-annales-des-empereurs-du-japon/oclc/5850691 OCLC 5850691] ==External links== * [[National Diet Library]], "The Japanese Calendar" [http://www.ndl.go.jp/koyomi/e/ -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before =[[Chōroku]] | title = [[Japanese era name|Era or ''nengō'']]
